head.title: Optical Realization of Quantum Gambling Machine

article.h1: Optical Realization of Quantum Gambling Machine

span.span: Yong-Sheng Zhang, Chuan-Feng Li, Wan-Li Li, Yun-Feng Huang, and Guang-Can Guo

Electronic address: gcguo@ustc.edu.cn Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department
of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, P.
R. China

div.p: Quantum gambling — a secure remote two-party protocol which has no classical counterpart — is demonstrated through optical approach. A photon is prepared by Alice in a superposition state of two potential paths. Then one path leads to Bob and is split into two parts. The security is confirmed by quantum interference between Alice’s path and one part of Bob’s path. It is shown that a practical quantum gambling machine can be feasible by this way.

As a kind of game, gambling plays an important role in the society and nature which are full of conflict, competition and cooperation. Up to now, game theory has been investigated with mathematical methods [1] and applied to study economy, psychology, ecology, biology and many other fields [2, 3].

One might wonder why games like gambling can have anything to do with quantum physics. After all, game theory is about numbers that entities are efficiently acting to maximize or minimize. However, if linear superpositions of the actions are permitted, games will be generalized into quantum domain [4, 5]. Quantizing games may be interesting in several fields [4], such as foundation of game theory, games of survival and quantum communication [6]. Moreover, quantum mechanics may assure the fairness in remote gambling [7].
In this letter, we present a quantum gambling machine composed of optical elements.

We may firstly investigate the simplest classical gambling machine: one particle and two boxes A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB. During a game, the casino (Alice) stores the particle in A𝐴italic-AA or B𝐵italic-BB randomly, then the player (Bob) guesses which box the particle is in. For the two parties do not trust each other, even a third party, a remote classical gambling is impossible. Whereas in the quantum domain, Alice may prepare the particle in a superposition state of |a⟩ket𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-a CLOSE:rangle\left|a\right\rangle (the particle in A𝐴italic-AA) and |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle (the particle in B𝐵italic-BB). If she generate the equal superposition state

div.p: and a prescribed box (e.g. B𝐵italic-BB) is sent to Bob, a remote fair gambling may be carried out. For simplicity, the bet in a single game is taken to be one coin. If Bob finds the particle in box B𝐵italic-BB (state |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle), he wins one coin, otherwise he loses the bet. Obviously, the probability for Bob to win is exactly 50%percent50NUMBER:50 POSTFIX:percent50\%. Moreover, Bob cannot cheat by claiming that he found the particle when he did not, for Alice can verify by opening box A𝐴italic-AA.
In order to decrease the probability for the particle in box B𝐵italic-BB, Alice may prepare a biased superposition state (she gets no advantage using an ancilla or other complex strategy [7])

However, the quantum principle assures that Bob has a chance to find out the difference and win her R𝑅italic-RR coins, which is the punishment the two parties agree on before the game.

Bob’s strategy is to split out part of the state |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle and convert it to state |b′⟩ketsuperscript𝑏′VERTBAR:| italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|b^{\prime}\right\rangle by performing a unitary operation, i.e.,

div.p: Where |b′⟩ketsuperscript𝑏′VERTBAR:| italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|b^{\prime}\right\rangle is orthogonal to |a⟩ket𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-a CLOSE:rangle\left|a\right\rangle and |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle and η𝜂italic-eta\eta is the splitting parameter. After the splitting, if Bob does not find the particle in box B𝐵italic-BB, Alice will send box A𝐴italic-AA to him for verification. In this case the state of the particle is reduced to |ϕa⟩=11+η⁢(|a⟩+η⁢|b′⟩)ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎11𝜂ket𝑎𝜂ketsuperscript𝑏′VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-eta ARG:end ARG:end OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-a CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-eta ARG:end VERTBAR:| italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:)\left|\phi_{a}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\eta}}\left(\left|a\right\rangle+% \sqrt{\eta}\left|b^{\prime}\right\rangle\right), if Alice prepare the particle in the equal superposition state |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\Psi_{0}\right\rangle. Therefore, the verification of Bob is to measure the particle under the basis |ϕa⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{a}\right\rangle and its orthogonal basis |ϕb⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{b}\right\rangle. If Alice prepare the biased superposition state |Ψ0′⟩ketsuperscriptsubscriptΨ0′VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\Psi_{0}^{\prime}\right\rangle, he may find the particle in state |ϕb⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{b}\right\rangle with a certain probability and win R𝑅italic-RR coins.

There exists an equilibrium for the two parties in this protocol [7]. Alice can ensure her expected gains no less than zero by preparing the equally distributed state |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\Psi_{0}\right\rangle. Bob can ensure his expected gains no less than a particular value only depending on R𝑅italic-RR by selecting an optimal splitting parameter η=η~⁢(R)𝜂~𝜂𝑅italic-eta RELOP:equals OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-eta ARG:end OPEN:( italic-R CLOSE:)\eta=\tilde{\eta}\left(R\right). In fact, this protocol is a zero-sum game, and the strategies of Alice and Bob are represented by different choices of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon and η𝜂italic-eta\eta, respectively.

In the experiment, a linear-polarized photon is employed as the particle. Similar to the simulation of quantum logic [8], two potential paths of the photon may serve as boxes A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB. |b′⟩ketsuperscript𝑏′VERTBAR:| italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|b^{\prime}\right\rangle are distinguished from |a⟩ket𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-a CLOSE:rangle\left|a\right\rangle and |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle by the polarization of the photon.

The setup of the optical quantum gambling machine is shown in Figure 1. A virtue of this machine is that all the detections are carried out automatically by the machine, which may help to eliminate the classical communication between the parties and prevent their cheating.

Initially, the photon is generated in a definite linear polarization state (such as vertical |V⟩ket𝑉VERTBAR:| italic-V CLOSE:rangle\left|V\right\rangle or horizontal |H⟩ket𝐻VERTBAR:| italic-H CLOSE:rangle\left|H\right\rangle) by a polarizer. Then the state is transferred to a superposition state of |V⟩ket𝑉VERTBAR:| italic-V CLOSE:rangle\left|V\right\rangle and |H⟩ket𝐻VERTBAR:| italic-H CLOSE:rangle\left|H\right\rangle with half waveplate (HWP) a𝑎italic-aa according to the preparation parameter ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon chosen by Alice. The preparation is accomplished by swapping the location and polarization states of the photon with polarizing beamsplitter (PBS) 11NUMBER:11 and the fixed HWP σxsubscript𝜎𝑥italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{x}. After the state swapping, the polarization is horizontal while the location is prepared in the required state |Ψ0′⟩ketsuperscriptsubscriptΨ0′VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\Psi_{0}^{\prime}\right\rangle.

Bob’s splitting is realized by adjusting the HWP b1subscript𝑏1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} according to the parameter η𝜂italic-eta\eta he selects. Then |b′⟩ketsuperscript𝑏′VERTBAR:| italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|b^{\prime}\right\rangle (split out by Bob) is separated from |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle via PBS 22NUMBER:22 and superposed with |a⟩ket𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-a CLOSE:rangle\left|a\right\rangle via PBS 33NUMBER:33. The verification is implemented with HWP b1subscript𝑏1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} and PBS 44NUMBER:44. HWP b1subscript𝑏1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} is adjusted according to η𝜂italic-eta\eta so as to assure that |ϕa⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{a}\right\rangle and |ϕb⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{b}\right\rangle are transmitted and reflected by PBS 44NUMBER:44 respectively. In order to obtain the result of the gambling, three detectors D1subscript𝐷1italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{1}, D2subscript𝐷2italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{2} and D3subscript𝐷3italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{3} are adopted to detect the photon in the state |b⟩ket𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle, |ϕa⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{a}\right\rangle and |ϕb⟩ketsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑏VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left|\phi_{b}\right\rangle, respectively.

A single game of gambling with this machine is described as follows. After Bob put in his bet — one coin, the machine will inform Alice and Bob to select the parameter ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon (adjusting HWP a𝑎italic-aa) and η𝜂italic-eta\eta (adjusting HWP b1subscript𝑏1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} and b2subscript𝑏2italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{2} simultaneously). Then a photon is generated from the polarizer and distributed to three parts. If the detector D1subscript𝐷1italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{1} or D3subscript𝐷3italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{3} responds, Bob win one or R𝑅italic-RR coins; if D2subscript𝐷2italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{2} responds, Bob loses the bet (then the bet will be conserved for Alice automatically).

To demonstrate the performance of the optical gambling machine, a beam (composed of independent identical photons) is generated instead of a single photon during the experiment, namely, a well polarized He-Ne laser (3mW at 632.8nm) is utilized as the light source. The results are shown in Figure 2, where P1subscript𝑃1italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{1} and P3subscript𝑃3italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{3} denote the probabilities that Bob win one and R𝑅italic-RR coins, P2subscript𝑃2italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{2} denotes the probability that Bob lose the bet. The probabilities are determined by the relative light intensities measured by the three detectors.

In order to illustrate Bob’s strategies, we suppose that Alice and Bob agree on R=5𝑅5italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:5R=5 at the beginning of the gambling. The expected gains of Bob are shown in Figure 3. Obviously, there exists an optimal splitting parameter η~⁢(5)≐0.27approaches-limit~𝜂50.27OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-eta ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:) RELOP:approaches-limit NUMBER:0.27\tilde{\eta}\left(5\right)\doteq 0.27 to assure his expected gains no less than a particular value despite Alice’s choice.

Optical approach has many advantages. By making use of two different freedom degrees of the photon (location and polarization), an optical quantum gambling machine may be realized conveniently with several HWPs, PBSes and detectors. Particularly, the decoherence of all-optical system is relatively low [9], while the protocol is very sensitive to the errors caused by the device and environment. As discussed by Goldenberg et al. [7], for a successful realization of quantum gambling, the error rate has to be lower than 2/R32superscript𝑅3italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\sqrt{2/R^{3}}. Since the error rate in the experiment is only about 140140FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:40 ARG:end\frac{1}{40}, a practical quantum gambling may be carried out with this optical machine under the condition R<14.4𝑅14.4italic-R RELOP:less-than NUMBER:14.4R<14.4.

Our experiment has shown that quantum gambling and quantum games have real physical counterpart, and a practical quantum gambling machine can be realized with simple optical devices. It can be expected that quantum mechanics may bring other interesting results in game theory.
